title: Clarify Target Patient Population and Specific Stroke Rehabilitation Goals
detail: The current claims describe the NeuroReach VR system's capabilities for reach and grasp training but lack specificity regarding the exact stroke rehabilitation goals (e.g., specific functional deficits addressed) and the target patient population (e.g., stroke phase, severity of impairment). Clarifying these aspects will allow for a more precise understanding of the system's intended impact and clinical utility.

title: Hypothesize the Impact of Gamification on Long-Term Adherence
detail: While the system is designed with gamified elements to increase motivation (c0001, c0002), the long-term effectiveness of these elements in promoting sustained user adherence to the rehabilitation program is not yet established. A hypothesis to explore is whether the gamified elements will translate into better long-term functional outcomes and patient engagement compared to non-gamified approaches.

title: Investigate the Clinical Efficacy of ARAT-Aligned Tasks
detail: The pouring task is designed to be ARAT-aligned (c0004), which is a recognized assessment tool. However, the evidence does not yet demonstrate the clinical efficacy of these specific ARAT-aligned tasks within the NeuroReach VR system in improving actual ARAT scores or other functional measures in stroke survivors. A next step would be to plan for clinical trials to validate this.

title: Clarify the Status and Implementation of All Projected Dashboard Metrics
detail: The projected dashboard is mentioned to display performance metrics (c0002), but only a partial list is provided, and the implementation status of each metric is not fully detailed. Clarification is needed on which metrics are fully implemented, which are in development, and how they will be used to inform the adaptive controller and patient progress tracking.

title: Hypothesize the Correlation Between Sensor Feedback Consistency and Rehabilitation Outcomes
detail: The system aims to provide multi-sensory feedback (c0001), but technical challenges with consistent haptic support and tilt estimation exist (c0003). A hypothesis to investigate is whether the consistency and reliability of this feedback directly correlate with the effectiveness of the rehabilitation, particularly in improving selective muscle activation and overall motor control.
